A (Not Entirely Novel) Problem with No Definitive Solutions

How can we extract meaningful information from a corpora of Renaissance texts using topic modeling?

Introduction

Digital humanities work promises researchers access to unthinkably large corpora spanning upwards of 278,000 books [1] and 300 billion words [2]. Computer scientists have effectively used these corpora to train increasingly-powerful Artificial Intelligence (AI) models. However, many of the insights in these corpora remain inscrutable to human researchers.

Blei [3] and others have described some of the valuable research which can arise from corpora-level analysis centered in the humanities. Corpora-level analysis allows researchers to examine the evolution of texts over time; search for specific topics; understand the influence of authorship; provenance; and other non-contextual features on literature’s themes, and more.

A major tool in doing this digital humanities work is topic modeling1, however, its difficulty represents a major stumbling block for new and experienced scholars alike. Broadly, we consider the motivations of topic modeling, adapted from [4], to be:

  • Organizing documents into thematic categories
  • Designing categories with appropriate levels of granularity and abstractness
  • Describing the evolution of those categories over time
  • Enabling a domain expert to analyze and understand the content
  • Finding relationships between categories
  • Understanding how authorship, origin, and other contextual features influence content

Metaphors, Irony, and Context

Corpora of historical literature share much of the same problem space as more modern corpora, however, they also present unique challenges.

Our Corpus

To explore race and politics in Renaissance literature—as well as develop new methods in the digital humanities—we are utilizing the Visualizing English Print corpus with standardized spellings generated from texts released by the Text Creation Partnership as part of the Early English Books Online corpus.

“Wishlist” for topic models

  • Choosing an optimal number (K) of topics
  • Coherent, distinct, and, non-ambiguous topics
  • Reasonable compute time for mid-size(?) corpora
  • Contextual understandings of KWIC

Better Evaluation

What’s going on?

Research Directions

Specific Work

  • Produce ground truth corpus
  • Understand race, politics over time

Broad Contributions

  • Conduct a comprehensive review of major research directions in topic modeling as they apply to the analysis of historical corpora
  • Design and evaluate ensemble models
  • Explore and design evaluation metrics from multistakeholder perspectives
  • Improve the computational efficiency of the Top2Vec library
  • Contribute to TopModel, OCTIS, and other topic modeling frameworks
  • Develop new models and a set of best practices for understanding metaphor, irony, and other context-dependent phrases
